articles.headline: Democrats Push a Budget to Fulfill Biden’s Aggressive Economic Ambitions
articles.snippet: The $3.5 trillion blueprint under consideration in the Senate would deliver, at least temporarily, on the economic promise of a unified Washington run by Democrats.
articles.abstract: The $3.5 trillion blueprint under consideration in the Senate would deliver, at least temporarily, on the economic promise of a unified Washington run by Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The $3.5 trillion budget blueprint that Democrats unveiled in the Senate this week promises to reshape the government’s role in the economy, in ways President Biden and his party have called essential to rebuilding the American middle class, lifting people out of poverty and tackling the threat of climate change.

articles.headline: ‘The Market Is Insane’: Cars Are Sold Even Before They Hit the Lot
articles.snippet: A shortage of computer chips is keeping automakers from producing enough cars to meet rising demand. Used cars are scarce, too.
articles.abstract: A shortage of computer chips is keeping automakers from producing enough cars to meet rising demand. Used cars are scarce, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rick Ricart is expecting nearly 40 Kia Telluride sport utility vehicles to arrive at his family’s dealership near Columbus, Ohio, over the next three weeks. Most will be on his lot for just a few hours.

articles.headline: Boston Overhauls Admissions to Exclusive Exam Schools
articles.snippet: A new policy will increase representation of Black and Latino students in the prestigious public schools, which serve as a gateway to elite colleges.
articles.abstract: A new policy will increase representation of Black and Latino students in the prestigious public schools, which serve as a gateway to elite colleges.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Long into the night on Wednesday, parents and students waited in line to say their piece about Boston Latin School and who deserves to attend it.

articles.headline: Haunted by Past Virus Surges, California Leans on Masks and Vaccines
articles.snippet: A new indoor mask requirement in Los Angeles County comes as new virus cases have nearly tripled statewide. Immunization rates, however, should keep any spike below past peaks.
articles.abstract: A new indoor mask requirement in Los Angeles County comes as new virus cases have nearly tripled statewide. Immunization rates, however, should keep any spike below past peaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Last month, flanked by the “Transformers” robot hero Optimus Prime and a bevy of Minions from the “Despicable Me” movie franchise, Gov. Gavin Newsom triumphantly stood before the Universal Studios Hollywood globe, lifting more than a year’s worth of pandemic health restrictions and announcing California’s “grand reopening.”
articles.byline: By Matt Craig, Mitch Smith and Shawn Hubler

articles.headline: What Ever Happened to IBM’s Watson?
articles.snippet: IBM’s artificial intelligence was supposed to transform industries and generate riches for the company. Neither has panned out. Now, IBM has settled on a humbler vision for Watson.
articles.abstract: IBM’s artificial intelligence was supposed to transform industries and generate riches for the company. Neither has panned out. Now, IBM has settled on a humbler vision for Watson.
articles.lead_paragraph: A decade ago, IBM’s public confidence was unmistakable. Its Watson supercomputer had just trounced Ken Jennings, the best human “Jeopardy!” player ever, showcasing the power of artificial intelligence. This was only the beginning of a technological revolution about to sweep through society, the company pledged.

articles.headline: Building Solar Farms May Not Build the Middle Class
articles.snippet: Some of the wealthiest companies in the world are investing in the green economy. But they’re not investing in paying union wages.
articles.abstract: Some of the wealthiest companies in the world are investing in the green economy. But they’re not investing in paying union wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear Democrats tell it, a green job is supposed to be a good job — and not just good for the planet.

articles.headline: Europe’s economic outlook has been clouded by the Delta variant.
articles.snippet: Virus cases are surging, governments are returning to economic restrictions and the postpandemic recovery now seems further away.
articles.abstract: Virus cases are surging, governments are returning to economic restrictions and the postpandemic recovery now seems further away.
articles.lead_paragraph: Across Europe, governments and businesses are maneuvering to try to stop a surge in coronavirus cases — driven by the rapid spread of the Delta variant — from hampering the continent’s recovery.
articles.byline: By Eshe Nelson, Jack Ewing and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Plans for free pre-K and community college could provide a ‘ladder into the middle class.’
articles.snippet: For at least a decade, many experts and advocates have called for expanding the public education system to level the playing field for students from “cradle to career.”
articles.abstract: For at least a decade, many experts and advocates have called for expanding the public education system to level the playing field for students from “cradle to career.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — What was once considered a progressive dream for the nation’s education system could be headed toward reality as Democrats push forward to broker a deal on a new spending plan containing President Biden’s most ambitious domestic policy goals.
articles.byline: By Erica L. Green and Madeleine Ngo
